When slain the blooming hero lies</br>Extended on the mournful bier,</br>Can nature check the swelling sighs?</br>Streams not the fond maternal tear?</br>Away the stoick's boasted pride,</br>Which quells the passions' plenteous tide;</br>While apathy with dull Saturnian reign,</br>Damps the sweet source of pleasure and of pain.

How vain with philosophic rules</br>To quell the torrent of desire!</br>Can the rude jargon of the schools</br>The bright heroic act inspire?</br>O fool!  whose unharmonious frame,</br>Dumb to the voice of praise or blame,</br>Ne'er felt the kindling transport glow,</br>Nor woo'd the dazzling laurel to thy brow.

Hail to the Druid's sacred song</br>Rejoice!  In glorious battle slain,</br>The restless spirit flies e'er long</br>To breathe its native air again;</br>Again ye seize the brazen shield,</br>Again the gleaming faulchion wield;</br>In Freedom's cause again ye go,</br>And brave the wintry blast, the mountain snow.

Where on the heath this lonely thorn</br>Its rude romantic branches waves,</br>And moping Sadness sighs forlorn</br>To ocean's deep-resounding caves,</br>Appal'd I view the dismal scene</br>Where purple slaughter dy'd the green;</br>When curst Rebellion's impious train</br>Rais'd the destroying sword, and aw'd the subject plain;

When the insidious child of Rome,</br>Big with the schemes of future fame,</br>Proud and audacious, durst presume</br>To breathe religion's hallow'd flame;</br>When o'er the soul with deepest shade</br>Her sable pall Ambition spread;</br>And Vengeance red with human gore,</br>Impell'd by France, sought Britain's distant shore.

Swift as along the liquid skies</br>Sails the tremendous Bird of Jove,</br>O'er Albion's hoary deeps he flies;</br>Whilst hate and mingled fury strove</br>To soothe the bodings of despair.</br>Then Discord rais'd her horrent hair,</br>Aloft her meteor eye-balls glow,</br>Emblems of death and quick succeeding woe.

Wide o'er the land with dreadful shade</br>Bellona shook the flag of war,</br>And matrons, pale with silent dread,</br>Beheld th' approaching conflict near.</br>In vain the wise, with anxious care,</br>Wearied the heavens with ceaseless prayer;</br>Unmov'd the rigid Fates remain,</br>And the young soldier flew to Preston's fatal plain.

Briton, if yet thou hast a soul</br>Where great sensations nobly flow,</br>Above the dregs of earth refin'd,</br>Congenial to the touch of woe;</br>O let thy generous heart inspire</br>New raptures to the glowing lyre,</br>And teach me thro' those parts to roam,</br>Where soaring Genius spreads his purple plume.

Hark, thro' the night's incumbent gloom,</br>Dim spectres utter solemn moans;</br>And stretch'd on ocean's dashing foam,</br>The spirit of the tempest groans;</br>Eager before the rising sun</br>To see the work of death begun,</br>Indented lightnings cleave the air,</br>And growling thunders mutter from afar.

'Tis done; the clarion's echoing note</br>Sounds thro' the hosts the shrill alarm,</br>And swift the swelling clangors float,</br>And bid the sleeping warrior arm.</br>Aloud the thundering cannon roars,</br>Rebellowing to the rocky shores;</br>Erect the foaming courier flies,</br>And the rude throng and hovering death defies.

They fly.  I view the conqueror's sword</br>Wet with my country's crimson stain;</br>I view the bleeding soldier gor'd,</br>The victim of tormenting pain.</br>Hide, Memory, hide th' inglorious tale,</br>Suspend thy kind concealing veil.</br>Shall Freedom stoop to lawless sway,</br>And go where frowning power shall point the way?

Lo!  in the very jaws of fate,</br>And blushing for his country's shame,</br>A hero scorns the base retreat,</br>And breathes the patriot's holy flame;</br>O'er falling ranks his steed he guides,</br>While round him stream the purple tides;</br>And hostile hands with deep dismay</br>Yield to his arm the honours of the day.

But, drench'd in blood of thousands slain,</br>The faulchion flames with horrid glare.</br>Barbarian, stay! — the stroke refrain;</br>That venerable hero spare.</br>In vain imploring pity calls;</br>Thy fame, thy boast, O Albion!  falls.</br>Grimly th' insulting victor smiles,</br>And the base dust his hoary hairs defiles.

O Gardner!  yet thy soul sublime,</br>Beyond the boast of mortal praise,</br>Shall triumph o'er the shafts of time,</br>And bright to latest ages blaze:</br>Glory shall sound, with loud acclaim,</br>The trumpet of eternal fame;</br>Affection all the griefs reveal,</br>And curse th' audacious villain's impious steel.

The sister arts with rival aid,</br>Sweet Poesy and Painting, join,</br>To tell how strictest virtue sway'd,</br>How valour rul'd that arm divine.</br>And ye whom various fortune leads</br>To Preston's billow beaten meads,</br>The patriot's holy shade revere,</br>And o'er the turf drop soft the gushing tear.

I, wrapt in sweet poetic dreams,</br>Beneath this rude encircling shade,</br>Behold the sun's departing beams</br>O'er Arthur's towering summit fade;</br>Revolving in my pensive mind,</br>The various fate of human kind;</br>And hear the village murmurs sound from far,</br>Where groans of murder swell'd the clang of war.</br>
